text: Adding to Ruben's question. If I calculate the expected value from BSP, does it make sense to estimate the variance that my strategy has using: Var[X] = E[X^2] - E[X]^2 ?

elements.text: Adding to Ruben's question. If I calculate the expected value from BSP, does it make sense to estimate the variance that my strategy has using: Var[X] = E[X^2] - E[X]^2 ?

text: I basically look at expected value and std when evaluating preplay strategies. And also when checking if a strategy that I have put live is performing as it "should"

elements.text: I basically look at expected value and std when evaluating preplay strategies. And also when checking if a strategy that I have put live is performing as it "should"

text: I think the numerical way is superior in this case, with fewer assumptions and lots of libraries to do what you want with one line of code

elements.text: I think the numerical way is superior in this case, with fewer assumptions and lots of libraries to do what you want with one line of code

text: IF your RV is normal the sample variance gives you an unbiased estimate of the population variance - that is why we use it in such cases isn't it? I can't see how you can calculate E[X^2] unless you know the p.d.f. ?

elements.text: IF your RV is normal the sample variance gives you an unbiased estimate of the population variance - that is why we use it in such cases isn't it? I can't see how you can calculate E[X^2] unless you know the p.d.f. ?

text: Is sample variance unbiased for other RV too?

elements.text: Is sample variance unbiased for other RV too?

text: We are using the central limit theorem and law of large numbers to justify the fact that in most cases you can use sample variance

elements.text: We are using the central limit theorem and law of large numbers to justify the fact that in most cases you can use sample variance

text: Yeah I get that you assume the sampling distribution is normal via CLT but I was asking about the formula that OP wants to use with E[X^2] terms  to calculate the theoretical variance of the RV that your sample contains realisations of? I agree with you - I would just use sample variance. I guess I am asking how you would even calculate Var(X) from the E[X^2]-E[X]^2 form without actually knowing the pdf. I guess it is unimportant it just aroused my curiosity as I have forgotten so many fundamentals over the years.

text: <@UUE6E1LA1> I bet pre-inplay, in a market with 2 runners it would be: Var[X] = prob_0 * X_0 ^ 2 + prob_1 * X_1 ^ 2 - E[X] ^ 2

elements.text: I bet pre-inplay, in a market with 2 runners it would be: Var[X] = prob_0 * X_0 ^ 2 + prob_1 * X_1 ^ 2 - E[X] ^ 2

text: X_i is the pnl I would get if runner_i wins, so X is the market's pnl

elements.text: X_i is the pnl I would get if runner_i wins, so X is the market's pnl

text: I'm not sure what do you mean by "I need to know the pdf". I know prob_0 and prob_1 because I use BSP prices. E[X] is calculated in the same way... Am I missing something?

elements.text: I'm not sure what do you mean by "I need to know the pdf". I know prob_0 and prob_1 because I use BSP prices. E[X] is calculated in the same way... Am I missing something?

text: I'll calculate the sample variance as <@U03JA9G6EEB> suggests and see what number I get :smile:

elements.text: I'll calculate the sample variance as
suggests and see what number I get

text: I think there was just some misunderstanding, so when you say you want to use E[X^2] - E[X]^2 the assumption is that you are solving this analytically and not numerically, but from my understanding, you are already computing the mean numerically using the sample mean 1/n * sum(X_i), so for the variance I would go again with the sample variance, if you are a python user you can do it using pandas/numpy

elements.text: I think there was just some misunderstanding, so when you say you want to use E[X^2] - E[X]^2 the assumption is that you are solving this analytically and not numerically, but from my understanding, you are already computing the mean numerically using the sample mean 1/n * sum(X_i), so for the variance I would go again with the sample variance, if you are a python user you can do it using pandas/numpy

text: I understand now. My sample mean is 0.84 (this is in EUR profit per market). And the sample variance is 408, now how do I interpret these results

elements.text: I understand now. My sample mean is 0.84 (this is in EUR profit per market). And the sample variance is 408, now how do I interpret these results

text: the interpretation is that you have an average profit of 0.84 EUR and than you can use the std (sqrt of variance) and say that 60% of the time you have results that are 0.84+- 4.5EUR

elements.text: the interpretation is that you have an average profit of 0.84 EUR and than you can use the std (sqrt of variance) and say that 60% of the time you have results that are 0.84+- 4.5EUR

text: Hope this helps <@U0155J92A7Q>

elements.text: Hope this helps

text: Sorry I wrote variance instead of std, but your point is clear.

elements.text: Sorry I wrote variance instead of std, but your point is clear.

text: So in 3000 markets, I would expect a profit of 3000 * 0.84 with a std of sqrt(3000 * 408) = 1106

elements.text: So in 3000 markets, I would expect a profit of 3000 * 0.84 with a std of sqrt(3000 * 408) = 1106

text: n * mean +- sqrt(n) * std I think is what you are after

elements.text: n * mean +- sqrt(n) * std I think is what you are after

text: Exactly! Actually, the analytical and numerical calculations for the variance yield very similar numbers, for my specific sample. While the expected value calculated analytically is different from the sample mean

elements.text: Exactly! Actually, the analytical and numerical calculations for the variance yield very similar numbers, for my specific sample. While the expected value calculated analytically is different from the sample mean

text: Just for the sake of clarification, I don't think you can solve this analytically because you don't know the pdf of your RV X, but you can do it numerically, estimating the mean with the sample mean and the variance with the sample variance.

elements.text: Just for the sake of clarification, I don't think you can solve this analytically because you don't know the pdf of your RV X, but you can do it numerically, estimating the mean with the sample mean and the variance with the sample variance.

text: I understand your point, and thanks for the clarification! I just estimate the pdf to be the BSP prices, but this may be wrong for some smaller markets
